intro: Rhus succedanea var. acuminata, commonly known as the staghorn sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the eastern and central United States. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are bright green in summer and turn vibrant red in autumn. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers that develop into red, fuzzy berries. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is adaptable to a variety of soil types. The staghorn sumac is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in disturbed soils.
